Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 43319 
Regional—Project Preparatory Technical Assistance (R-PPTA) 
October 2010 
 
 
 
Greater Mekong Subregion: Preparing the Corridor 
Towns Development Project 
(Cofinanced by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund 
under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing 
Partnership Facility) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  GMS  –  Greater Mekong Subregion 
  IEE  –  initial environmental examination 
  Lao PDR  –  Lao People’s Democratic Republic 
  RCSP  –  regional cooperation strategy and program 
  SPAR  –  subproject appraisal report 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—Project preparatory technical assistance (R-PPTA) 
Targeting classification  –  Targeted intervention: geographical poverty issues (TI-G) 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Water supply and other municipal infrastructure and services 
(water  supply  and  sanitation,  waste  management,  other 
municipal services, urban sector development) 
Theme (subtheme)  –  Economic growth (widening access to markets and economic 
opportunities) 
Climate change  –  Climate change adaptation 
Location impact  –  Urban (high), regional (high), national (medium) 
Partnerships  –  Korea  Export-Import  Bank,  Japan  International  Cooperation 
Agency,  Agence  Française  de  Développement,  German 
development  cooperation  through  KfW,  Kuwait  Fund,  and 
Organization  of  the  Petrol  Exporting  Countries  Fund  for 
International Development, or others (to be determined during 
the project preparatory TA) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars unless otherwise stated. 
 
 
Vice-President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations 2 
Director General  K. Senga, Southeast Asia Department (SERD) 
Director  J. Lynch, Transport and Urban Development Division, SERD 
   
Team leader  F. Steinberg, Senior Urban Development Specialist, SERD 
Team members  M. Buendia, Social Development Specialist (Resettlement), SERD 
  E. Fischelis, Counsel, Office of the General Counsel 
  M. Ortega, Assistant Project Analyst, SERD 
  A. Velasquez, Environment Specialist, SERD 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The proposed project preparatory technical assistance (TA) is in support of the regional 
cooperation strategy and program (RCSP) (2011–2013) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for 
the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS).1 The project preparatory TA was prepared at the request of 
the participating governments of Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR), and 
Viet Nam through a reconnaissance mission in March 2009 and a TA fact-finding mission in 
August–September 2009. The project preparatory TA has the concurrence of the participating 
governments which have endorsed the proposed impacts, outcome, and outputs of the ensuing 
investment project, the proposed implementation and financing arrangements, and the terms of 
reference for the consultants. The concept paper was approved on 9 August 2010.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The RCSP for the GMS aims to help achieve the GMS vision of a prosperous, integrated, 
and harmonious subregion through the pursuit of four strategic pillars: (i) strengthening connectivity 
and facilitating cross-border movement and tourism; (ii) integrating national markets to promote 
economic  efficiency  and  private  sector  development;  (iii)  addressing  health  and  other  social, 
economic, and capacity building issues; and (iv) managing the environment and shared natural 
resources to help ensure sustainable development and conservation of natural resources. The 
proposed assistance is consistent with the strategic pillars of the current RCSP, specifically with 
regard  to  improving  health  and  poverty  levels  and mitigating  environmental  degradation. The 
project will contribute to the implementation of ADB’s Strategy 2020 for regional cooperation and 
integration, and accelerate the economic integration of Association of Southeast Asian Nations.3 
 
3.  The focus on corridor town development is a new approach to maximize the economic 
benefits of increased trade and traffic flows along the major transport corridors in the GMS. Several 
corridor towns are located so strategically that they can boost investment and economic activity. With 
the necessary enabling environment in place—such as proper strategic economic development plans, 
adequate infrastructure and public services, and institutional capacity to guide and manage future 
development  and  investment—corridor  towns  can  also  successfully  attract  private  sector 
investments  for  economic  infrastructure  such  as  market  centers,  agro-business,  agricultural 
processing zones, industrial parks, transport terminals, and logistics facilities. These corridor towns 
can play an important role for a cluster of settlements in their respective hinterlands. 
 
4.  The challenges facing many corridor towns in the GMS are significant. Some towns are 
simply unable to cope with the rapid growth of migrants seeking new employment opportunities, 
and find their infrastructure and public services totally inadequate. Severe environmental problems 
due to capacity constraints in water supply, sanitation systems, and solid-waste management are 
common,  and  increasing.  Furthermore,  the  absence  of  land  use  planning  and  regulations  is 
contributing to increased congestion and haphazard development. Decisions on the location of 
industrial  activities,  for  example,  are  often  made  in  the  absence  of  environmental  impact 
assessments and rigorous site selection criteria. As traffic and trade increases along the GMS 
transport corridors, there is an urgent need to strengthen the capacities of towns to manage 
development in an environmentally and socially sustainable manner. The planned development of 
these towns will induce further regulated growth in their surrounding areas and strengthen the 
economic vitality and investment attractiveness of the corridors. 
 
5.  The Southern Economic Corridor (SEC) and the East–West Economic Corridor (EWEC) 
                                                
1  ADB. 2010. Regional Cooperation Strategy and Program: Greater Mekong Subregion, 2011–2013. Manila. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB's website on 20 October 2009. 
3  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. Manila.

2   
provide the starting point for defining the geographic focus for the proposed project. Selection of 
the corridor towns was based on various criteria, including (i) economic potential as border towns, 
industrial  hubs,  market  centers,  transshipment  points,  and/or  their  tourism  attributes;  (ii) 
infrastructure constraints on accommodating future growth and/or attracting private investment; 
and  (iii)  expressed  interest  and  commitment  to  dedicate  the  necessary  resources  towards 
sustainable economic growth and development. The proposed project will cover 10 towns along 
the EWEC and SEC—five border towns and five corridor towns. The infrastructure in the selected 
towns is insufficient to service the increasing populations and foster trade, private investment and 
local economic development. There are four towns in Cambodia (Battambang, Bavet, Neak Leung, 
and Poipet), three in the Lao PDR (Dansavanh, Kaysone Phomvihane, and Phine), and three in 
Viet Nam (Dong Ha, Lao Bao, and Moc Bai). The towns are economically diverse, with primary 
industries that include agriculture, manufacturing, trade, and/or tourism. The towns of Kaysone 
Phomvihane  and  Battambang  have  the  largest  populations  (both  in  excess  of  100,000);  the 
remaining towns generally have populations of less than 50,000. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
6.  The project preparatory TA is required to establish the basis for the proposed investments 
and capacity development activities. It is designed to facilitate the transformation of the GMS 
transport corridors into fully fledged economic corridors through priority infrastructure investments 
and capacity building support in selected corridor towns (including border towns). 
 
7.  The GMS  program  has  placed  considerable  emphasis  on  developing  priority transport 
corridors in order to link countries together and to promote trade, tourism, and investment in the 
subregion. Investments in roads and bridges have established and strengthened physical links 
throughout the GMS and provided the foundation for more efficient transport of goods and people. 
Taking the development process one step further requires the transformation of these transport 
corridors into fully fledged economic corridors. In contrast to transport corridors, economic corridors 
attract investments which, in turn, promote economic growth and development along the corridors. 
While border areas are often the most visible places of increased economic activity, villages, towns, 
and cities located along the corridors can also attract new investments if the necessary incentives 
and enabling conditions are in place. The availability of basic infrastructure and public services, for 
example, is a necessary but not sufficient precondition for investment and sustainable economic 
development;  regulatory  frameworks  and  commitment  are  complementary  requirements.  This 
development strategy of transforming transport corridors into fully fledged economic corridors has 
gained momentum and was highlighted as a priority initiative at the 15th Ministerial Meeting of the 
GMS Economic Cooperation Program.4 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  Based  on  the  design  and  monitoring framework  (Appendix  1),  the  impact  will  be  that 
corridor  towns  have  adequate  urban  infrastructure  and  services,  thereby  contributing  to  the 
economic transformation of transport corridors in the GMS. The outcome of the TA is the agreed 
design of the resulting project. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  For each of the corridor towns included in the project preparatory TA, the principal outputs 
are: (i) a strategic local economic development plan, (ii) an infrastructure investment program for 
                                                
4  The 15th Ministerial Meeting of the GMS Economic Cooperation Program was held in Cha Am, Thailand on 17–19 
June 2009.

3 
priority urban infrastructure, and (iii) clearly defined institutional arrangements and the necessary 
capacities to implement the strategic development plan and infrastructure investment program. 
These three outputs are also essential for the corridor towns to attract private investment and to 
ensure the sustainable management of future development opportunities as well as challenges. 
The project preparatory TA, as also shown in the Design and Monitoring Framework will be 
structured along the following three major outputs: 
 
10.  Output 1: Strategic local economic development plans. This output will provide the 
necessary analytical and advisory services to prepare strategic local economic development plans 
in each of the participating corridor towns. Assessments will be undertaken of each corridor town's 
current economic base by identifying core industries and services, and  then analyzing future 
development opportunities and constraints that take into account predicted growth in population, 
traffic, and investment, along with needed institutional and policy reforms to ensure sound urban 
management. The plans will identify suitable areas for new development of different land uses, 
including  commercial,  residential,  industrial,  and  agricultural  activities,  as  well  as  indicate 
environmentally sensitive areas for protection. In addition, to help guide future development, the 
plans will also identify possible clusters of economic development, and assist the corridor towns 
determine the types of economic activities that can be promoted for private sector investment. The 
participatory nature of preparation of these strategic local economic development plans provides 
support to the project implementation units; they will have a key role to play. 
 
11.  Output 2: Develop investment programs for priority urban infrastructure. The planning 
process will serve as the basis for identifying infrastructure constraints and deficiencies in the 
corridor towns and prioritizing an investment program. Strategic investments under the ensuing 
project will consist of basic urban infrastructure such as water supply and sanitation (including 
wastewater treatment), drainage, access roads and bridges, solid-waste management, and public 
markets and transport terminals. While investments in essential urban infrastructure are necessary 
to  accommodate  future  growth  and  development,  these  investments  can  also  catalyze  new 
investments.  In  this  context,  consideration  will  also  be  given  to  leveraging  infrastructure 
investments by the public sector to attract private sector investments in, for example, industrial 
parks, agro-industrial development zones, logistics centers, and cross-border facilities. Additionally, 
infrastructure that can be financed through public–private partnerships will also be identified. The 
investment program will be supplemented by safeguards studies of impacts on the environment, 
resettlement, and indigenous people. Initial environmental examinations will be carried out during 
the project preparatory TA, but no significant environmental impacts are expected. Preliminary 
analysis based on existing data indicates no land acquisition and involuntarily resettlement will be 
required for subprojects. An indigenous peoples development plan will be developed (if required) 
under ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). 
 
12.  Output  3:  Strengthen  institutional  capacities  for  project  implementation  and 
sustainable  development.  In  addition  to  strategic  development  plans  and  infrastructure 
investment programs, the emergence of fully fledged economic corridors requires that towns have 
the institutional capacities to manage development as well as promote investment opportunities to 
the  private  sector.  Capacity  building  assistance  will  support  the  preparation  of  strategic  local 
economic  development  plans,  and  implementation  of  infrastructure  investments.  The  capacity 
development output will contribute to the fine-tuning of implementation arrangements. Since private 
sector investments are the lifeblood of dynamic economic corridors, innovative means to attract 
private sector investments and to structure public–private partnerships will be a critical area for 
institutional strengthening and capacity building in the corridor towns.  
 
13.  Under the project preparatory TA, technical due diligence will prepare detailed designs for 
prioritized  subprojects  and  identify  subsequent  batches  of  subprojects  to  be  prepared  during

4   
project implementation. The project will be a project loan. The due diligence will also cover (i) an 
assessment of economic internal rates of return and financial internal rate of return for all subprojects; 
(ii) a financial management assessment of all executive agencies to confirm capacity to manage 
the  project  finances;  (iii)  development  of  procurement  plan  according  to  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to 
date); and (iv) conduct of poverty, social, and gender analysis and preparation of a poverty and a 
social strategy, a gender action plan, and a participation strategy. Initial safeguard screening will 
cover the environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous people, as indicated in the initial 
poverty and social analysis (Appendix 2). 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The estimated cost of this project preparatory TA is $2.3 million equivalent, of which $0.8 
million will be financed from ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV) and $1.2 million by 
the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund under the Regional Cooperation and Integration 
Financing Partnership Facility of ADB. The governments of Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam 
will finance the remaining $0.3 million equivalent. The governments of Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and 
Viet Nam have been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing 
project. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The project preparatory TA will be implemented by three executing agencies: the Ministry of 
Public Works and Transport in Cambodia in collaboration with the newly created provincial councils, 
the Ministry of Public Works and Transport in the Lao PDR, and the provincial governments (such 
as the provincial people's committee of Quang Tri Province) in Viet Nam. The three participating 
executing agencies will form country steering committees that will provide overall guidance at the 
national level, and coordinate the Corridor Towns Development Project (CTDP) implementation 
issues with peer country steering committees. The implementing agencies will be the participating 
towns,  which  will  establish  project  implementation  units  in  their  public  works  departments 
(Cambodia and Viet Nam) and the Urban Development Administration Authorities (the Lao PDR). 
The  preparation  of  the  project,  and  particularly  the  formulation  of  strategic  local  economic 
development  plans,  will  be  participatory  in  nature  and  include  public  and  private  sector 
stakeholders. The TA will be implemented over eight months starting January 2011. 
 
16.  The TA for the preparation of the GMS CTDP will require about 130 person-months of 
consulting services, consisting of 30 person-months of international services and 100 person-
months of national services, as elaborated in the outline of terms of reference for consultants 
(Appendix 4). The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Consulting firms will be engaged using 
the quality- and cost-based selection method with a quality cost ratio of 80:20. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
 
17.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis for the Greater Mekong Subregion: 
Preparing the Corridor Towns Development Project.

Appendix 2  7 
INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS  
 
Country/Project Title:  Regional/Greater Mekong Subregion: Corridor Towns Development Project  
 
Lending/Financing  Project Loan  Department/  Southeast Asia Department 
Modality:  Division:  Transport and Urban Development Division 
 
I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
  Poverty in the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) is still substantial in Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic 
Republic (Lao PDR), and Viet Nam, where its incidence ranges from 9% to 34% of the population. Through the 
development of economic corridors in the GMS, new opportunities will be created following the development of 
existing and new towns along those corridors (particularly the East–West and Southern corridors) and at the 
borders of the GMS countries.  
B.  Targeting Classification 
1.  Select the targeting classification of the project: 
   General Intervention     Individual or Household (TI-H) 
   Geographic (TI-G)      Non-Income MDGs (TI-M1, M2, etc.) 
 
2.  Explain the basis for the targeting classification:  
  The interventions are nationwide. The project will contribute to poverty reduction indirectly through developing 
urban areas, development of human capital and human development, public governance.  
C.  Poverty Analysis 
1.  If the project is classified as TI-H, or if it is policy-based, what type of poverty impact analysis is needed? 
 
2.  What resources are allocated in the project preparatory technical assistance (TA)/due diligence? 
  Among the national consultants, there are the following specialists who will deal with poverty analysis and due 
diligence, among other things: (i) social preparation and community development specialists (15 person-months), 
(ii) resettlement specialists (15 person-months), (iii) water and sanitation engineers (15 person-months), and (iv) 
flood control and drainage engineers (15 person-months). 
 
3.  If general intervention, is there any opportunity for pro-poor design (e.g., social inclusion subcomponents, 
cross subsidy, pro-poor governance, and pro-poor growth)? 
  The proposed project will pursue the following outcomes: (i) increased access by citizens and economic 
enterprises to basic public infrastructure (and also improved urban/public service provision); (ii) enhanced local 
economic development through infrastructure facilities, and increased employment and income opportunities; 
(iii) improved financing facilities of infrastructure investments, including public–private partnerships in financing and 
implementing basic urban services programs; (iv) addressing of climate change through investments in solid-waste 
management and sewerage, both of which are emitters of greenhouse gases; and (v) improved local government 
capacities and empowered local institutions and organizations (including enhanced urban management capacity). 
II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
A.  Initial Social Analysis 
Based on existing information: 
1.  Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit 
from the project? 
  The potential beneficiaries are residents and businesses operating in the selected towns. The poor and 
socially excluded are expected to benefit from new job opportunities and increased local economic activities. They 
will benefit from the improved access to urban services, both improving their physical environment and health and 
their business operations and competitiveness. 
 
2.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? 
  The needs of beneficiaries related to stable and adequately paid employment and improved access to basic 
urban infrastructure. The project will directly contribute to: (i) reduced infrastructure backlogs, (ii) increased 
economic productivity of targeted towns, and (iii) improved income and employment opportunities of the affected 
population. Thus, in terms of benefits, the poor shall directly benefit from improved urban services, and indirectly 
benefit from improved employment opportunities and increase productivity of their towns. 
 
3.  What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the project 
address them? 
  Some of the economically active population of these towns is expected to settle in the closer physical range of 
the border towns, possibly in informal settlements. To mitigate the proliferation  of informal settlements  and slums,

8  Appendix 2 
it is proposed to invest in these border towns in guided land development to accommodate new residents and to 
steer urban development 
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1.  Indicate the potential initial stakeholders. 
  Local government units, private sector companies, and communities as beneficiaries of urban services. 
 
2.  What type of consultation and participation is required during the project preparatory TA or project processing 
(e.g., workshops, community mobilization, involvement of nongovernment organizations and community-based 
organizations, etc.)? 
  Consultation of communities regarding specific services which have a direct impact on their lives (water 
supply, sanitation, solid waste, etc.) will be undertaken during subproject preparation. This will focus on technical 
issues and the willingness and ability to pay for these services. Consultation and participation will be applied in 
case of resettlement. Beneficiaries, local private sector representatives, nongovernment organizations, and local 
authorities will be involved in all stages of program implementation to ensure its sustainability. The risk of 
speculators or developers buying land from the community is a social risk that can be mitigated through a public 
information campaign to ensure that people are aware of the project benefits as well as the potential risks and 
consequences of being bought out by speculators or developers. Additionally, if specific areas or zones are 
earmarked for development under the project, it is possible to require that ADB safeguard policies apply to 
development projects in these areas, and supersede the national laws if there are differences. 
 
3.  What level of participation is envisaged for project design? 
    Information sharing        Consultation 
    Collaborative decision making      Empowerment 
 
4.  Will a consultation and participation plan be prepared?    Yes            No    Please explain. 
  Subproject planning and design will entail intensive qualitative analysis directly involving project beneficiaries 
through the extensive use of participatory methods to identify the local poor population and the infrastructure 
provisions  that  may  better  fit  their  needs.  Multistakeholder  workshops  will  be  held  to  discuss  subproject 
formulation and implementation, and additional community consultations will be held following the approval of the 
subprojects. A consultation and participation plan will be prepared for cases of resettlement made necessary by 
civil works. 
C.  Gender and Development 
1.  What are the key gender issues in the sector/subsector that are likely to be relevant to this project/program? 
  Women will be fully represented in subproject design to ensure that infrastructure provisions reflect women’s 
needs. Particular attention to women will be also given in the location of infrastructure facilities (water, sanitation, 
solid-waste management, markets). Health and income-generation benefits of the proposed project will reflect 
women’s needs. Women will have equal participation in local economic development activities. 
 
2.  Does  the  proposed  project/program  have  the  potential  to  promote  gender  equality  and/or  women’s 
empowerment  by  improving  women’s  access  to  and  use  of  opportunities,  services,  resources,  assets,  and 
participation in decision making?      Yes          No    Please explain. 
  A gender action plan will be prepared, where applicable. The plan will refer to (i) infrastructure (water, 
markets) that meets women's needs, and (ii) economic development promoting women's entrepreneurship.  
 
3.  Could the proposed project have an adverse impact on women and/or girls or to widen gender inequality? 
    Yes          No    Please explain   
  It is expected that the gender action plan will mitigate any adverse impacts.

IV. PROJECT PREPARATORY TA/DUE DILIGENCE RESOURCE REQUIREMENT

Appendix 4  11 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The regional cooperation strategy and program for the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) 
(2009–2011) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB)1 aims to help achieve the GMS vision of a 
prosperous, integrated, and harmonious subregion through the pursuit of four strategic pillars: 
(i) strengthening connectivity and facilitating cross-border movement and tourism; (ii) integrating 
national  markets  to  promote  economic  efficiency  and  private  sector  development; 
(iii)  addressing  health  and  other  social,  economic,  and  capacity  building  issues;  and 
(iv)  managing  the  environment  and  shared  natural  resources  to  help  ensure  sustainable 
development and conservation of natural resources.2 The proposed assistance is consistent 
with the strategic pillars of the current regional cooperation strategy and program, specifically 
regarding improving health and poverty levels, and mitigating environmental degradation. The 
project will contribute to the implementation of Strategy 20203 for regional cooperation and 
integration, and accelerate Association of Southeast Asian Nations economic integration, which 
covers  five  areas:  (i)  developing  investment  projects,  including  infrastructure  to  support 
transport networks, trade logistics, and modernization of agriculture; (ii) enhancing support for 
community-based  ecotourism  development;  (iii)  hastening  implementation  of  projects  that 
advance  the  environmental  management  and  climate  change  agenda;  (iv)  strengthening 
relationships  with  local  governments  and  the  private  sector;  and  (v)  intensifying  capacity 
development.4 
 
2.  The GMS countries pursue a joint strategy to convert their recently created transport 
corridors  into  fully  fledged  economic  corridors,  as  has  been  stressed  by  the  recent  15th 
Ministerial  Meeting  of  the  GMS  Economic  Cooperation  Program  (17–19  June  2009).  To 
enhance economic growth and productivity in the economic corridors, border towns and new 
urban  growth  centers  need  effective  management  through  integrated  development  of 
infrastructure and planned and systematic project, policy, and institutional interventions. The 
proposed project will trigger a number of subregional projects and generate synergy with other 
ongoing  initiatives  of government  and  ADB-supported  programs  as  well  as  those  of  other 
development partners. 
 
3.  The  project  preparatory  technical  assistance,  as  also  shown  in  the  Design  and 
Monitoring Framework, will be structured along the following three major outputs: Output 1: 
Strategic local economic development plans; Output 2: Develop investment programs for priority 
urban infrastructure; Output 3: Strengthen institutional capacities for project implementation and 
sustainable development. 
 
4.  The major outputs and activities are summarized in Table A4.1. 
                                                
1  ADB. 2010. Regional Cooperation Strategy and Program: Greater Mekong Subregion, 2011–2013. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2008. Greater Mekong Subregion: Maturing and Moving Forward. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
4  President  Kuroda  during  the  5th  Brunei-Indonesia-Malaysia-Philippine  East  Asia  Growth  Area  Cooperation 
Summit, 29 February 2009, Hua Hin, Thailand.

12  Appendix 4 
 
 
Table A4.1: Summary of Major Outputs and Activities 
Expected  Expected 
Major

1.  Preparatory activities  January 2011  Inception  February 
1.1  Conduct stakeholder consultations  report  2011

IEE = initial environmental examination; PAM = project administration manual; PPP = public–private partnerships; 
RRP = report and recommendation of the President; SWOT = strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats; 
TA = technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
B.  Consulting Services 
 
5.  The TA for the preparation of the GMS Corridor Towns Development Project will require 
about 130 person-months of consulting services, consisting of 30 person-months of international

Appendix 4  13 
services and 100 person-months of national services. The summary of services required is 
contained in Table 4.2. 
 
Table 4.2: Summary of Consulting Services Requirement 
International  National 
Person- Person-
Position  Position 
Months  Months 
Urban management specialist and team  8  Water and sanitation engineers    10 
leader    Social preparation and community    10 
Finance and procurement specialist  6  development specialists   
Social safeguards and resettlement  6  Town planners    10 
specialist    Flood control and drainage engineers    10 
Environmental safeguards specialist  6  Institutional development and    10 
Capacity development specialist  4  procurement specialists   
Financial analysts    10 
Environmental specialists    10 
Resettlement specialists    10 
Solid waste specialists    10 
Geographic information specialists    10 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
1.  International Consultants 
 
6.  The consulting firm will provide 30 person-months of international consultant input. 
 
(i)  Urban  management  specialist  and  team  leader  (8  person-months),  with 
preferably more than 10 years team leader experience. The consultant will 
assess the demand among the local government units for the proposed financial 
facility, provide an institutional and physical planning framework for the proposed 
project,  consider  the  lessons  of  other  programs,  determine  the  appropriate 
funding mechanism, and undertake project preparation and packaging activities. 
(ii)  Finance  and  procurement  specialist  (6  person-months),  with  preferably 
more than 10 years of experience. The consultant will assist the team leader in 
the  above  tasks,  and  prepare  the  financing  plans  of  the  proposed  project. 
Related to procurement, the specialist will assist the executing agencies and 
implementing  agencies  prepare  contract  packages,  bid  documents,  and 
procurement advance actions. 
(iii)  Social  safeguards  and  resettlement  specialist  (6  person-months),  with 
preferably more than 10 years of experience. The consultant will assist the 
team leader and the team in preparing and finalizing social action plans and 
resettlement  plans  for  all  proposed  subprojects  if  and  where  required.  This 
specialist,  with  social  science  or  planning  background,  will  focus  on  gender 
action plans, indigenous peoples, and resettlement plans. 
(iv)  Environmental  safeguards  specialist  (6  person-months),  with  preferably 
more than 10 years of experience. The consultant will assist the team leader in 
preparing the initial environmental examination (IEE) or summary IEE, covering 
all proposed subprojects. 
(v)  Capacity development specialist (4 person-months), with preferably more 
than 10 years of experience. The consultant will design a capacity development 
plan in accordance with the institutional framework of the project.

14  Appendix 4 
 
2.  National Consultants 
 
7.  National  consulting  firms  will  provide  100  person-months  of  national  consultants, 
including  the  three  national  co-team  leaders  (one  each  in  Cambodia,  the  Lao  People’s 
Democratic Republic [Lao PDR], and Viet Nam). The person-months listed below will be spread 
evenly over Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam.  
 
(i)  Water and sanitation engineers (10 person-months), with preferably more 
than 10 years of experience. The consultants will be responsible for overseeing 
the demand assessment, engineering aspects, and costing of pilot subprojects, 
and assist in preparation of subproject appraisal reports (SPARs) and project 
design documents. 
(ii)  Social  preparation  and  community  development  specialists  (10  person-
months), with preferably more than 10 years of experience. The consultants 
will (a) oversee the demand assessment for related subprojects and collaborate 
with the resettlement specialist in preparation of resettlement plans; (b) identify 
how the proposed project relates to national priorities as identified in the national 
poverty reduction strategy (or other national development plan), ADB’s country 
poverty analysis, and sectors identified as priorities in ADB’s country partnership 
strategy; (c) conduct a gender analysis (including a gender-inclusive participatory 
risk assessment, and adequate mitigation measures) for each participating town; 
and (d) ensure that the opportunities for women’s entrepreneurship development 
be explored and incorporated in the ensuing project design. A gender action plan 
will be prepared, where applicable. 
(iii)  Town planners (10 person-months), with preferably more than 10 years of 
experience. The consultants will oversee urban planning aspects of SPARs and 
project  design  documents,  and  assist  in  preparing  SPARs  and  project  design 
documents. 
(iv)  Flood control and drainage engineers (10 person-months), with preferably 
more  than  10  years  of  experience.  The  consultants  will  oversee  demand 
assessment for related subprojects and the engineering aspects and costing of 
pilot  subprojects,  assess  flood  control  and  drainage-related  capacity 
development  requirements  for  the  project,  and  assist  in  SPARs  and  project 
design documents. 
(v)  Institutional development and procurement specialists (10 person-months), 
with preferably more than 10 years of experience. The consultants will design 
capacity development plans for project implementation and assist in preparing 
SPARs and project design documents. Related to procurement, the specialists 
will assist the international finance and procurement specialists in developing 
local implementation arrangements for the proposed project. The institutional 
development  specialists  will  assist  the  executing  agencies  and  implementing 
agencies  in  preparing  contract  packages,  bid  documents,  and  procurement 
advance actions. 
(vi)  Financial analysts (10 person-months), with preferably more than 10 years 
of experience. The consultants will assess demand among the local government 
units for the proposed financial facility, the design of the appropriate funding 
mechanism  for  project  implementation,  and  the  development  of  criteria  and

Appendix 4  15 
procedures  for  fund  management,  and  assist  in  SPARs  and  project  design 
documents.5 
(vii)  Environment specialists (10 person-months), with preferably more than 10 
years  of  experience.  The  consultants  will  assist  in  preparing  the  IEE  or 
summary  IEEs,  and  the  environmental  assessment  and  review  framework 
covering all proposed subprojects. 
(viii)  Resettlement specialists (10 person-months), with preferably more than 10 
years of experience. The consultants will oversee preparation of resettlement 
plans involving the communities of affected persons, assess the resettlement-
related capacity development requirements, and assist in SPARs and project 
design documents. 
(ix)  Solid-waste specialists (10 person-months), with preferably more than 10 
years of experience. The consultant will oversee the demand assessment for 
related  subprojects,  oversee  the  engineering  aspects  and  costing  of  pilot 
subprojects,  identify  technologies  suitable  to  waste  management  that  can 
achieve capture of and/or use the landfill gas, assess the solid-waste-related 
capacity development requirements for the project, and assist in SPARs and 
project design. 
(x)  Geographical information specialists (10 person-months), with preferably 
more than 5 years of experience. The consultant will oversee the production of 
thematic maps as required for the production of SPARs. 
 
                                                
5  In the case of the Lao PDR, project preparation could be utilized to leverage a policy discussion on the role of the 
Urban Development Administration Authorities.

metadata.Subject: Issues, impacts, methodology, key activities, cost, financing and implementation arrangements for Preparing the Corridor Towns Development Project in Greater Mekong Subregion.
metadata.Title: Preparing the Corridor Towns Development Project (Cofinanced by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility)

author_page:
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  GMS  –  Greater Mekong Subregion 
  IEE  –  initial environmental examination 
  Lao PDR  –  Lao People’s Democratic Republic 
  RCSP  –  regional cooperation strategy and program 
  SPAR  –  subproject appraisal report 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—Project preparatory technical assistance (R-PPTA) 
Targeting classification  –  Targeted intervention: geographical poverty issues (TI-G) 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Water supply and other municipal infrastructure and services 
(water  supply  and  sanitation,  waste  management,  other 
municipal services, urban sector development) 
Theme (subtheme)  –  Economic growth (widening access to markets and economic 
opportunities) 
Climate change  –  Climate change adaptation 
Location impact  –  Urban (high), regional (high), national (medium) 
Partnerships  –  Korea  Export-Import  Bank,  Japan  International  Cooperation 
Agency,  Agence  Française  de  Développement,  German 
development  cooperation  through  KfW,  Kuwait  Fund,  and 
Organization  of  the  Petrol  Exporting  Countries  Fund  for 
International Development, or others (to be determined during 
the project preparatory TA) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars unless otherwise stated. 
 
 
Vice-President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations 2 
Director General  K. Senga, Southeast Asia Department (SERD) 
Director  J. Lynch, Transport and Urban Development Division, SERD 
   
Team leader  F. Steinberg, Senior Urban Development Specialist, SERD 
Team members  M. Buendia, Social Development Specialist (Resettlement), SERD 
  E. Fischelis, Counsel, Office of the General Counsel 
  M. Ortega, Assistant Project Analyst, SERD 
  A. Velasquez, Environment Specialist, SERD 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.
